subject: Project 3 FAQ
content: Refer to this post for Frequently Asked Questions regarding Project 3.  Project 3 is due October 22 at 8 pm.  Please keep the followups related to questions in this post only.. . Additional project slides for general overview and tips on the project: @1554..  . Q: I've never played Euchre before, how do I learn the rules of the game?. A: Pages 2-5 of the spec detail the rules of "EECS 280 Euchre". Also, a staff member from prior semesters made a video tutorial a few years ago that may be helpful: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M0jGJ0NRcrc. 0:33 Dealing. 1:55 The Upcard / Making Trump Round 1. 5:35 Making Trump Round 2. 7:20 Leading the First Trick. 8:20 The Other Players Play Cards in the First Trick. 10:58 Deciding who Wins the First Trick. 11:24 Leading the Second Trick. 12:00 Playing the Rest of the Hand. 20:30 Scoring. 21:23 Determining Whether Another Hand should be Played - Ending. . Q: Can I add helper functions while implementing the Player classes?. You are allowed to use helper functions, but these helper functions should not change the interface of the class. So within your implementations of the class's member functions, feel free to call helpers. But in your test files, you should not assume that these functions exist (because you should not alter the interface for the classes). This also applies in your euchre driver as well! e.g. If you add a helper function to the simple player class, you can use it within that class, but you can't use it in the driver since it won't be part of the Player interface!.  . This is especially important because when we run your test cases against an intentionally buggy solution, that solution will not have your specially defined helper functions! So just use the interfaces of each class when you test them.. . Q: Why am I getting a compiler error for calling sort? . Note that the sort function modifies the hand. You cannot modify member variables in a const function, so you'll receive a compiler error you call sort in a const member function.. . You shouldn’t need to sort using card less. When you print the hand in order it should be sorted using the < operator. You could sort with card less when determining what action to take, but you should be able to find the min/max card in the hand without sorting. You could use a functor to sort using card less, but those are only covered later in the course. Generally: if you need to use sort, just the default one will be fine..  . Q: Why am I passing euchre public test, but failing euchre public test with solution card, pack, and player?. This means that when your euchre.cpp is run with the instructor solution implementations of card, pack, and player you produce incorrect output. This likely means that you're making an incorrect assumption about what functionality should go in card/pack/player versus in the game of euchre. For example, make sure that you're not printing output in player.cpp that should be printed in euchre.cpp. .  . Q: Why won't pack.in open in pack public tests when running on Xcode?. Click on the name of your scheme in the toolbar at the top left, Edit Scheme > Options > Enable "Custom Working Directory" and press the little folder icon. Pick the folder that contains your code along with pack.in. This will ensure that the file is visible to your executable. This is usually not a problem, and we are investigating the issue..  . Q: How do I debug and add in command line arguments with XCode/VSCode/VS?. Follow this link  and click on your specific IDE, then click on the "Arguments and options" subsection..  . Q: Should I be printing the incoming arguments from the command line?. Yes, according to the spec: "First, print the executable and all arguments on the first line. Print a single space at the end, which makes it easier to print an array.". . Q: Do I need to worry about the human player doing (insert illegal move) during the game?. No, in accordance with the spec you can assume that a human player will follow the rules of the game and will not attempt to cheat.. . Good luck and happy coding!. . extraorpinary

subject: Can't clone partner's git files
content: RESOLVEDMy partner followed the steps for version control for a team, and the starter files are in the "master" branch, with a README in the "main" branch on gitlab. She added me to the gitlab project as a "maintainer" as well. I have tried to clone the starter files from the gitlab project, but all I can clone using the HTTPS link is the README, and not the starter files in "master". How do I fix this?
i_answer: Glad you got it resolved! For anyone else having this issue, the problem is Git uses `master` as the default branch name but GitLab recently started using `main` is its default: https://about.gitlab.com/blog/2021/03/10/new-git-default-branch-name/ - so, you might end up in a situation where your repo has two different branches and your changes are getting pushed to these different branches rather than to the same one.. . The most straight-forward fix would be to agree between your partner on which branch you want to use, and make sure locally that you're only working on that branch e.g. if you wanted to just use `main`, you would run the command. ```. git checkout main. ```. There might be other issues too, like what if you had a bunch of changes on `master` that you wanted to move over to `main`, or how to get rid of `master` so you only have one branch - that's a little harder to explain in piazza post and it might vary by your individual situation, so I'd recommend going to office hours if you have that question

subject: local test versus autograder
content: My local test passed both the crab and dog test.  However, in my autograder, all of the image fails on the energy matrix test..
i_answer: The autograder is what matters, since the autograder is running on Linux, you should test your code on Caen Linux. There are likely some differences between how it runs on a Mac/windows, and Linux.

subject: matrix_at Question
content: I'm confused about how to set a new pointer to "pointing" at the value of a member of the matrix struct (data).  . . As arguments for this function we have *mat pointer, column #, and row #.  In my mind, the way to set this new pointer is to index through data (in the Matrix struct) with respect to the given column # and row # (these translate into the # of elements in array 'data').  It's at this point that I want to use a pointer initialized at the top of the function (i.e:   int* ptr;) to point to this value in 'data'.. . Then I return the pointer ptr.  The problem being, each time I try to translate this into code, I get errors.  ptr = mat -> data[(row and column iterator).    This is my thought process can anyone help me work through this?
i_answer: I think the problem you're having is that the subscript operator (`[]`) automatically dereferences the pointer, so you're trying to assign a value (an `int`) into a pointer. I think you need to use the address-of operator (`&`) on the right sign of the assignment for it to work.. . Also, worth mentioning that if you're assigning a pointer to `ptr` then returning `ptr`, you can just directly return the pointer you're trying to assign into `ptr`.
